body: Bumping this. We often have customers complaining metrics on UI do not show up. Most of the times it is because their topology is too large.
@objmagic - any update on this?
probably merge this in later this week, or next week.

@objmagic are you sure this is the reason? I've also heard that the problem with large topologies in the UI is that the UI has to make a very large number of concurrent requests to tracker fetch all the metrics it needs to render. When the UI requests metrics from tracker, is tracker pulling and aggregating from TMaster synchronously?

@billonahill 

You are right. UI <-> Tracker also has design problem/performance issue.
Thanks for the effort! Merged.

After investigation, found `if (server_->Start() != 0) GTEST_FAIL();` failed due to port conflict.
In all Heron tests, the server ports are hard coded
@maosongfu - this might be ok for unrecoverable exceptions. But for recoverable exceptions, you should not die, just like that. How can you distinguish between the two?
Shall we also update comments [here](https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1839/files#diff-cf2b0320c00a0fc85f039efe83786ecfR215)?

Nice work.

(actually I am happy to see at the first time that not properly piping I/O from subprocess could lead to such bad error...)
closed via #1836
cannot reproduce so close for now
Thanks for reviewing. Yeah this was an interesting one to track down, learned a lot about python and its interaction with subprocesses and also about stderr vs stdout buffering.
@ajorgensen last comment: why [this dependency](https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1840/files#diff-a39e34d854c69ea9a9bdee31d6947b20R188)?

@objmagic ah sorry I just copied another pex test block and didnt look too closed. I'll remove that dependency if its not actually used.

I believe all of the other pex_test blocks in this file have this as a requirement, this test seems to work without it though.
@objmagic What comments you think to update?
@maosongfu add something like "will fail fast if `Error` is encountered" at [here](https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1839/files#diff-cf2b0320c00a0fc85f039efe83786ecfR215)
@objmagic I think it is same as the comment I did on Ln236?
@maosongfu oh ok then.
please fix CI.

I saw there are:
`com.twitter.heron.api.Config.setEnableAcking(conf, true);` 
and 
`com.twitter.heron.api.Config.setNumStmgrs(conf, 1);`

For those storm samples, do you want to use storm traditional configs:
`conf.setNumAckers(1);`
and
`conf.setNumWorkers(1);`

In this way we could avoid using heron directly in storm examples.
LGTM. 👍
@nlu90 - this limits some of the resource specifications where you could specify componentRam etc - which makes Heron tuneable?
@ajorgensen - @srkukarni also encountered this when he was working with C++ api for Heron.
@kramasamy People can still access Heron specific config, for instance componentRam, like: https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1842/files#diff-b3d9497f7486aba1bca1cc5387948820R60

@maosongfu - but that exposes the underlying heron api which we should not do. Heron API will undergo a lot of changes as other higher level apis are being developed. You can think of the api such as setComponentRam, etc as storm extensions and let them reside in the Storm config itself - as it was orginally.

@kramasamy 
First, lets distinguish high level APIs and storm-extension level APIs:
- APIs in this pull request are storm-extension and are **low-level**. Definitely we can have another API jar called storm-api-extension providing these interfaces. But then why not just call heron? 
- For high level APIs. I would favor for another high level APIs jar, which is on top of heron, providing features to make develpers life easier, for instance, window supports.

Second, lets make sure the goal of heron-storm-compatibility: it is designed for easy migration from storm to heron; it is **not** for providing more features: new features are in heron.

If people want heron features, they should use heron API. These interfaces do not exist in Apache Storm, and people should use these interfaces explicitly with heron Config to reflect they are using some features on Heron, rather than Storm. 
Mixture of these two makes things ugly and hard to trace, i,.e, Hard to reason and hard to debug.
Also, even if we expose heron API features under storm namespace, it is in fact still **heron-api**, since: 
-  we own and maintain this part of code. 
- people need to bundle their projects with heron's jars.  (When people develop project with apache-storm, they will have no ways to access these APIs.)

On the one hand, it can not provide more benefits than simply calling heron api. On the other hand, it increases maintainence cost.

@objmagic @kramasamy I ran the tests locally and they all pass, the failures looked to be caused by 

```
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM warning: INFO: os::commit_memory(0x00000000eab00000, 40894464, 0) failed; error='Cannot allocate memory' (errno=12)
#
# There is insufficient memory for the Java Runtime Environment to continue.
# Native memory allocation (mmap) failed to map 40894464 bytes for committing reserved memory.
# An error report file with more information is saved as:
```

Looks like the ci machines may need some more memory or is there some other recourse?
The issue this PR addresses is not really urgent, so we can leave this PR open until Monday when @billonahill can give his comments. Still targeting this in 0.14.7.2 though.

@ajorgensen 

I just read this PR again but I failed to understand why memory usage issue could happen. However, I observed that integration tests were running fine for first 3~4 tests, but started having problem afterwards.

Let's try this:
1. sleep 5 seconds after an integration test finishes
2. run `ps` and dump its output on terminal. Just want to make sure processes spawned by test have exited.
3. sleep another 5 seconds
4. run next integration test

What do you think?

@objmagic yeah I wonder if these changes impacted the interaction in the integration tests. I'll take a look and see if something jumps out. All of the other prs look like they have passing tests so I think its somewhat safe to say this change introduced some difference in the way the integration tests work.

I've been testing this PR internally this week, and it functions well. I am in favor of merging this soon.

Does anyone here have any more comment?
@ajorgensen Agree. I am quite lost here since I did not expect such non-invasive change could blow up memory... We have to fix this issue to get this important PR merged.
@huijunw I deleted your comment because it exposed too much Twitter internal information, e.g., hostname.

got it

the log said 
Failed to fetch results after 15 attempts

So far:
1. No one is using heron-python for prod
2. The heron-python does not meet the production level of reliability and stablity.
3. They are not with high-priority.

I would sugguest we can turn off thoese heron-python unit tests or mark them flaky for now, if it hurts normal travis building. Also, we would ask people to take their own risks for using heron-python.

@objmagic it looks like the processes are no longer being properly cleaned up during the integration tests which leaves them around ultimately consuming all the memory available. I'll look into why this is happening.

Latest commit should fix the issue, going to wait for it to go through ci to confirm but I was able to see the issue and the resolution locally as well, it just turned out my machine has more memory than the ci machines do :)
@ajorgensen you are right. nice observation.
This reminds me that I may need to use thread as well in [result.py](https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/tools/cli/src/python/result.py) to prevent deadlock.
@huijunw You can just change `0.01` to `0.03`. I did this for Python test for before.
CI is good now. Merged. Thanks! @ajorgensen

Why not just change that line in the setter to the following? Why do we even convert seconds to strings?
```
conf.put(Config.TOPOLOGY_MESSAGE_TIMEOUT_SECS, secs);
```
It's not clear to me why breaking the inheritance is the best fix for this issue.

[Note: This is an example of why it's generally preferable to use custom types (e.g., `Duration`) over primitives, similar to the refactor we did to use `ByteAmount` over primitives. By doing that we don't run into issues like these.]

-1
This PR seems like we're taking a step backwards with our improvements to types, like `ByteAmount`, to work around another problem regarding seconds (#1841), which could be improved with better typing (i.e. `Duration`). With this change we're no longer storing `ByteAmount` objects, but we're instead storing string representations of integer representations of bytes (or MB, GB?). Even worse, we provide a static helper on `c.t.heron.api.Config` to take a well typed object like `ByteAmount` and then swallow it into a string? Instead, why not fix the seconds use a new `Duration` object and move towards better typing, not away from it.

@billonahill 

This PR keeps storing `ByteAmount` objects for ram related settings if you take a closer look at the changes. E.g, https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1842/files#diff-932b57c1a82df361bb7446cf9380e87cR58. 

The only difference is now user needs to call the static method provided in `heron.api.Config` to set them. This is reasonable because those ram settings(container ram, component ram) are more concepts in Heron not in Storm. The previous way of the config works just mix concepts from heron and storm together, while now the config for storm and config for heron are separated by breaking this inheritance.

Better typing is a good idea and we do need to move toward to it. But given the fact that our users are blocked by this bug for migration now and `Duration` object introduces a lot of changes in other places, I would prefer we do those changes in another separate PR. This could benefit our users' migration progress as well as us to keep issues separate.

@billonahill Thanks for the idea and the discussion. I've created two issues #1845, #1846  to tracking the problems we found during our discussion.

I'll merge this PR to unblock the release process for now.
closing as is duplicate of https://github.com/twitter/heron/issues/1769
@aahmed-se - there is a PR waiting to be merged actually. https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1776
@ananthgs - can you write a good concise PR description about how it works with ECS?
@ananthgs - you might want to add a detailed documentation of how to set it up and use, as described in other schedulers for heron.io. However, this can be done in a different PR.

-1 - even I am not happy with this PR - since it is exposing Heron API, which is something that will change extensively. Instead a storm extensions config - extensions to the Config of Storm is a good enough. Not sure why this was needed in the first place.
Any updates on this PR?

@kramasamy 
Extensions to the Config of Storm by adding more interfaces explicitly, is a bit different from making Config of Storm inheriting from Config of Heron directly.
I saw @billonahill comments, and it did mention some good points.

Currently the Config of Storm inherits from Config of Heron directly, which is error-prone and actually it does become a **bug** during topologies migration inside Twitter.
So even if we want to add extensions to the Config of Storm, it would be better to:
1. Revert Config of Storm back extending Map, rather than Config of heron. (What this pull request does) 
2. Add those features as methods explicitly. 

And I saw @nlu90 has created an issue for it: https://github.com/twitter/heron/issues/1845

no idea why.
@kramasamy may know the reason.

also how to declare custom variable for host.
declare -a hosts=(ec2-xx-xxx-xxx-xxx.compute-1.amazonaws.com ec2-xx.xxx.xx.xx.compute-1.amazonaws.com ec2-xx-xxx-xx-xx.compute-1.amazonaws.com)

how to replace custom variable on scp -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa user@xx.xxx.xx.xx:%s x.xxx.xx.xx place.
@ajorgensen you guys also run on EC2, correct? If so could you review this to see if your approach and this approach could coexist in this codebase?

The scp node needs to be available to all other nodes. The client uploads to it and all nodes download from it. If its going down, you will run into problems with this approach.

Please use the mailing list for questions instead of opening tickets. Closing this. Please continue the discussion on the list if you have additional questions.
LGTM. I just realized you did not sign https://engineering.twitter.com/opensource/cla. Can you sign it?
Done

1. FileUtils.deleteDir unit tests are added
2. All failed unit tests due to refactoring are fixed
3. Refactored CheckpoingManagerServerTest to use CountDownLatch instead of Thread.sleep()
4. Changed the general OBJECT type to MAP type for the ConfigKey.

Though the ConfigKey brings type check, I feel it is complicated to compose the code and hard to generalize for situations like nested configs and complex value types. We need to investigate if this part could be improved.

@billonahill we dont actually use ECS at all in our environment. I looked through the changes and they all look pretty self contained so I dont think there would be any negative impact to our usage of heron with mesos.

My intuition is that this issue requires us to do a comprehensive analysis of current design of Tracker API endpoints. For example, we need to figure out how to improve API so that thousands of API calls to Tracker can be batched into one API call. That said, I think this issue could not be solved in a short amount of time. However, this could be the most often complaint we receive from customers.

Refactor the code:
1. rename `localFileSystemBackend` to "localFileSystemStorage" in `LocalFileSystemStorageTest.java`
2. rename `CheckpointManager.start` to `CheckpointManager.startAndLoop` in `CheckpointManager.java`

This change can break the interfaces provided by Heron. Are there ways we could:
- precisely match the name of optional args' key, or
- distinguish the scope heron itself's configs from the scope of user's configs, just like bazel using `--` as a separator?

Let use -- since it is standard in python/gnu/hazel etc.

Sent from my iPhone

> On May 12, 2017, at 10:43 PM, Maosong Fu <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> This change can break the interfaces provided by Heron. Are there ways we could:
> 
> precisely match the name of optional args' key, or
> distinguish the scope heron itself's configs from the scope of user's configs, just like bazel using -- as a separator?
> —
> You are receiving this because your review was requested.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
>
+1 for @kramasamy suggestion if it can work

Unfortunately, this does not solve the root cause at all. What if user passes some argument with prefix `heron`? You will see the same error. And more annoyingly, this problem is not due to our mistake, not due to our users either.

The root cause is that **Python 2.7 argparser module is full of crazy shit**. Excuse me again for the foul language, but if you have experience with using other command line parsers in other languages, and you have ever read through the entire documentation of argparser APIs, you have no choice but wholeheartedly agree with me. Python 3 fixed this problem by allowing a `(allow_abbrev=False)` which can give you **exact** match. But this solution to me is like fixing a wall of shit by throwing at it more shit.

I have no strong opinion with @kramasamy's suggestion of using `--`, as long as you can implement it and add comprehensive tests! Another way of solving this problem is [here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/10751356)

Also, I prefer to solve this issue by not requesting changes from users' side (or you can say by not breaking Heron client's current behavior). Imagine users come to ask us "hey my script does not work. what has happened?", and you have to say "we did the following **breaking** change and you need to change accordingly"... 

That said, `--` solution is not as good as [this one](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10750802/disable-abbreviation-in-argparse/10751356#10751356). Let us solve this issue as transparent to users as possible.
Also, your PR forgot to change all the places that access argument values. For example, [here](https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/tools/cli/src/python/submit.py#L106).
@objmagic already -- works in heron client and it is a consistent behavior across the language.
ok. whatever is fine to me.

Plz fix eariler broken unit tests in https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1831 first rather than hurry for new codes. Otherwise it will block and slow down the whole heron migration process at Twitter; and consequently slow down the whole stateful processing features.

@maosongfu @srkukarni I agree we need to fix failed unit tests. But please do not worry about our internal migration process since currently release is always cherry-picked. That said, we can always control what we want to put into our next release.
Why shall we Replace `Charset.forName("UTF-8")` to `StandardCharsets.UTF_8`?
It's more strongly typed and has compile time checks built in.
As a discussion result, we will ask our users to add "--" to fix the problem. And this solution is verified working internall. So I'll close this pr

After some investigation, the cause of the failure is:  Client and server are running in separate threads and client trying to connect to the server before the server is started.  

The fix is to let the client connect to server only when the server is started.
See additional discussion and an alternate approach in PR #1858.
Also: CI.
LGTM, but please fix the failed test before merge the changes.
These changes are merged from another PR: #1820, thus closing this duplicate one
ping @kramasamy. Can you give an approval?
ping @kramasamy. Any more comments?
Split this PR into 2 separate smaller ones: #1861 #1862, for easier and fast reviewing. This PR will be closed
@objmagic we're not changing any user-facing APIs, just the internal `SystemConfig` getters used by internal heron classes.

Nothing's been decided about Trident at this point. This was the main feature that was blocking it, and after discussions with @mfu we realized it was easy to implement so I added it. There's a not a lot to supporting direct grouping, since it's very similar to custom grouping, so now that it's been developed we might as well add it IMO, regardless of Trident.

the last commit a86f8b4 includes 
1. some code refactoring in the `IStateManager.java` for easier reading
2. updated `getStatefulCheckpoint ` to `getStatefulCheckpoints`
Fixed in PR #1860.
do we plan to use `Instant` to represent an instantaneous point on the time-line in future refactoring?
@huijunw yes, I think it would be good for us to use `Instant` to represent points in time in a follow up PR.
